docs.abstract: Chinese dissident artist Ai Weiwei announces that a court in Beijing has agreed to hear his lawsuit against the city's tax authorities. (S)

headline.main: China: Court to Hear Artist's Lawsuit

docs.snippet: Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist, said Tuesday that a court in Beijing had agreed to hear his lawsuit against the city’s tax authorities.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist, said Tuesday that a court in Beijing had agreed to hear his lawsuit against the city's tax authorities. Mr. Ai is suing the officials for bringing a tax case against him. Tax officials have said Mr. Ai's company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development, owes the equivalent of $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai said he did not owe that amount and has argued that his wife, Lu Qing, is formally in charge of the company. Mr. Ai was detained for 81 days last year and has continued to mock the Chinese government and the Communist Party since his release.

headline.main: In China, Volkswagen Outsources Product Plan to the People

docs.snippet: The People's Car Project, in which the automaker solicited ideas for future urban mobility, received nearly 120,000 submissions.
docs.lead_paragraph: When an automaker decides to crowdsource ideas for its product line, it could do worse than canvassing the biggest crowd in the world.

docs.abstract: Last week, while the rest of the world was reading about the daring exploits of the blind activist Chen Guangcheng, most Chinese citizens knew nothing about it, not even the half-billion mainlanders with Internet access. So what were the Chinese reading about all week?

headline.main: Stray-Cat Barbecue, Dirty Tap Water, Celebrity Hijinks, No Chen - the Usual

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Berkman Center for Internet and Society

docs.snippet: Last week, while the rest of the world was reading about the daring exploits of the blind activist Chen Guangcheng, most Chinese citizens knew nothing about it, not even the half-billion mainlanders with Internet access. So what were the Chinese read
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG - It sounds quite preposterous, of course, this idea that 1.3 billion people could be kept wholly in the dark about a news event in their own country, an event that was simultaneously making headlines in the rest of the world.

headline.main: Amnesia as the West Judges China

docs.snippet: Two different Chinese men — one hotheaded cop, one blind activist escaping house arrest — chose to flee to an American diplomatic outposts as a refuge. But is United States’ style freedom the answer for China?
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK -- The two men have little in common. One is a hotheaded cop who liked to whip out his pistol and was an inspiration for the Chinese television series ''Iron-Blooded Police Spirits.'' The other is a soft-spoken blind activist who advocated for women and the disabled, and who irked the authorities enough to suffer their iron-blooded spirits firsthand. But the apparatchik and the dissident, the insider and the outsider, were of similar mind on one count. When each man fell into danger, he rushed to the sovereign diplomatic territory of the United States.

headline.main: A Chinese Composer Sounds Off About Music and Politics

docs.snippet: A leading contemporary composer in China says the country is backward in a range of educational and cultural areas, including music, even though Chinese musicians and composers do extremely well abroad.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Ye Xiaogang, artistic director of the Beijing Modern Music Festival and one of China's leading contemporary composers, is a quicksilver personality who laughs wryly, exudes determination and likes to dress in black. Just back in Beijing from receiving a prestigious Guggenheim Foundation award for music in the United States, Mr. Ye helped make musical history for arranging a performance in Beijing last Saturday of the ''Happiness Suite'' by Ma Sicong, marking the centennial of Mr. Ma's birth. A widely admired violinist and composer, Mr. Ma composed in 1937 one of China's most popular tunes, ''Nostalgia.''

docs.abstract: Researchers measured heart rates, blood pressure and biomarkers in 125 doctors before, during and after the 2008 Olympic Games.

headline.main: An Olympic Respite From Air Pollution

docs.snippet: Researchers measured heart rates, blood pressure and biomarkers in 125 doctors before, during and after the 2008 Olympic Games.
docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese officials clamped down on air pollution during the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, giving researchers an unusual opportunity to assess the effects of polluted air on the risks for cardiovascular disease.

docs.abstract: Dr Junfeng Zhang study in The Journal of the American Medical Association finds that the cardiovascular health of 125 young doctors improved during the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, due to a short-term reduction in air pollution. (M)1

headline.main: Vital Signs: Hazards: An Olympic Respite From Air Pollution

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.snippet: Chinese officials clamped down on air pollution during the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, giving researchers an unusual opportunity to assess the effects of polluted air on the risks for cardiovascular disease.     Researchers examined 125 healthy young d
docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese officials clamped down on air pollution during the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, giving researchers an unusual opportunity to assess the effects of polluted air on the risks for cardiovascular disease. Researchers examined 125 healthy young doctors, average age 24, before, during and after the Games, measuring their heart rates and blood pressure and testing their blood for various biomarkers associated with cardiovascular disease and death. The scientists found that blood levels of P-selectin, CD40 ligand and von Willebrand factor, all markers of inflammation, significantly declined during the Olympics, when the air was cleaner.

headline.main: Chinese Manufacturing Activity Slows Further, Survey Shows

docs.snippet: New data confirms that the Chinese economy is struggling to regain momentum and cementing expectations that Beijing will step up efforts to prop up growth.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG -- A closely watched survey showed that manufacturing activity in mainland China had sagged in May, confirming that the Chinese economy was struggling to regain momentum and cementing expectations that Beijing would increase efforts to prop up growth. A preliminary reading of the survey, which is published by HSBC and the financial information provider Markit and offers one of the earliest glimpses of the Chinese economy's performance each month, fell to 48.7 in May from 49.3 in April, HSBC said Thursday.

docs.abstract: Chen Guangfu, a brother of Chinese legal activist Chen Guangcheng, slips through the security cordon around his village and makes his way to Beijing to advocate on behalf of his son, who is jailed there on attempted homicide charges after attacking several plainclothes officers who had broken into the family home. Photos (M)/

headline.main: With One Brother in New York, Another Makes Escape

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HUMAN RIGHTS AND HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS

docs.snippet: Chen Guangfu, a brother of Chen Guangcheng, slipped through a security cordon and went to Beijing, said a lawyer who met him there.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Mia Li and Zhang Wei contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- A brother of the legal activist Chen Guangcheng, whose decision to seek refuge in the American Embassy here prompted a diplomatic standoff between China and the United States, has himself slipped through the security cordon around his village and made his way to the capital, according to a lawyer who met him on Thursday. The brother, Chen Guangfu, said he had come to Beijing to advocate on behalf of his son, who has been in police custody since he attacked a group of plainclothes officers who had broken into the family home in their search for Chen Guangcheng, according to the lawyer, Ding Xikui.
